ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about Chinese lending structures, as well as the broader implications of sovereign lending. I also got the opportunity to produce original research and apply my data analysis skills.
I learned a lot about Chinese lending, international finance and political economy.
how do countries pay back sovereign debt, differences between Chinese sovereign lending and lending from other lenders, why countries borrow from China, what they do with Chinese lending, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Sundquist assigned a variety of interesting readings pertaining to the topic, most of which was easy enough to understand even for someone without much of a polisci background.
I loved this course!! The final project challenged me to produce original work, and I am proud of my final product. The seminars and readings were engaging and well chosen.

Strengths: Really interesting readings, great course layout, interesting discussions

Weaknesses: Course material started becoming a little bit repetitive towards the end, would prefer if there were more topics incorporated

The strengths are that the course is very well designed, all the readings are well selected, the workload is well balanced and Dr. Sundquist is excellent at facilitating class discussions. Can't really think of any weaknesses, maybe just that I thought we were gonna discuss institutions like AIIB but never really did.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!! If you want to learn about Chinese lending and Chinas role in the world, as well as produce your own research, this is the class for you.

Yes! This is probably my favorite GLBL class I've taken at Yale. You learn a lot about a really relevant topic, and you also engage in your own research which is really exciting. It's not very challenging to do well if you stay engaged with the material, and Prof. Sundquist designs the class in a really fun way. From discussions to debates to simulations, you will not regret taking this class!

YES. You not only learn about which countries borrow from China, why they do, and what unique characteristics Chinese lending has, but also gain a stronger understanding of Chinese government/political system/businesses. The course will also put China in the context of the international system and examine sovereign lending in general, including from the US and other international lenders, and it will look at China pretty objectively. It is a perfect GLBL class that draws equally from economics and political science. James is a great instructor. He's very dedicated to the class and does an amazing job explaining concepts and facilitating class discussions. The workload is the perfect amount that keeps you very engaged with the class and is still manageable. I appreciate that the class isn't just discussing the readings we did (which I find boring and pointless with a lot of seminars) because James brings something more to the class content each time (and he brings us Chinese tea!). Overall this is a very well designed class, and I highly recommend anyone regardless of background to take it.
